1. Which best describes your understanding of compound interest?
  • I know what compound interest is, and I know how it’s calculated
  • I know what compound interest is, but I’m not sure how it’s calculated
  • I do not know what compound interest is
Good!
Brush up on your knowledge
Compound interest is the interest you earn on your money, plus the interest it's already accrued. It is calculated by multiplying the principal amount by one plus the annual interest rate. After the first year, the principal amount becomes the total amount including interest previously earned. So, if you start with $100 and earn 5% interest, you would calculate 100 x 1.05 to get $105. The following year, you would calculate 105 x 1.05 to get $110.25, and so on. To see how this works, try our compound interest calculator.
2. What is the S&P 500?
  • An online news blog for investors
  • A list of the 500 most profitable companies in the world
  • An index that tracks the stocks of 500 large U.S. companies
That's correct.
No.
The S&P 500 tracks 500 large U.S. companies and is the primary benchmark for large-cap stocks in the U.S. It provides a sense of the market's overall performance.
3. True or false: When you purchase a stock, that means you’re a partial owner of the company.
  • True
  • False
That's correct.
No.
Stocks are shares of ownership in a publicly traded company.
4. What is a dividend?
  • The rate at which interest compounds
  • Money paid by a company to its shareholders
  • The difference between what you bought an investment for and what you sell it for
That's correct.
No.
A dividend is a periodic payout of earnings that some companies and funds share with investors just for being a shareholder. Companies generally pay dividends to encourage people to invest in them.
5. How is a company’s share price determined?
  • The Federal Reserve
  • Supply and demand in the market
  • The company’s board of directors
  • New York Stock Exchange (NYSE)
That's correct.
No.
Stock exchanges, like the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq, track supply and demand, which helps determine the price at which securities trade.
6. What is the Dow Jones?
  • An index tracking the stocks of 30 large U.S. companies
  • A marketplace where investors can buy and sell stocks
  • An investing-related podcast
That's correct.
No.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average is composed of 30 stocks that are considered to be blue-chip companies. These companies are selected for inclusion in the index because they're leaders in their industries. Like the S&P 500, the Dow average can be a good indicator of the market's overall performance.
7. True or false: Novice investors should focus on timing the market to maximize their investments.
  • True
  • False
That's correct.
No.
Generally speaking, investors should focus on the long term. Day-to-day fluctuations can be difficult to predict and many experts say timing the market is impossible. Stciking with the market long term usually pays off as stocks have always increased in value over longer periods of time. Instead of trying to time the market, experts recommend regularly buying assets at set intervals, a strategy known as dollar-cost avergaing.
8. What does it mean when a stock has a high P/E ratio?
  • The stock is expected to increase in value
  • The stock is expected to decrease in value
That's correct.
No.
A stock’s price-to-earnings, or P/E, ratio measures a stock’s profit against its per-share earnings. If a stock’s P/E ratio is high, that usually means it’s highly valued by investors, who are willing to pay a higher price today based on expectations of future growth. (A high P/E can also be a sign that the stock is overvalued.) If the P/E ratio is low, that indicates it’s selling at a relatively cheap price.
9. How long do you have to hold a stock for it to be considered a long-term investment for tax purposes?
  • One year
  • Two years
  • Five years
  • 10 years
That's correct.
No.
When you sell an investment that you've owned for less than a year, the profit is taxed at the same rate as your income. After a year, it's taxed at the capital gain rate, which is 15% for most people.
10. Do all stocks pay dividends to investors?
  • Yes
  • No
That's correct.
No.
Companies can choose whether to pay dividends to their investors. More than 80% of the companies in the S&P 500 currently pay dividends.
